In the photo, George is pictured with his group members; the field officer is on the far left.

loans.use: to source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Alizhan

texts.ru: Алижан – веселый, добродушный и жизнерадостный человек. Ему 42 года,  женат,  отец троих детей.  Алижан -  шахтер, работает на шахте в г. Казарман по 15 дней в месяц. Пять лет назад, в поисках дополнительного источника дохода для своей семьи, Алижан начал свой бизнес в разведении скота и реализации сельхозпродукции на местном рынке.  Начав со стартовой суммой в 10,000 сом (KGS), на сегодняшний день его ежемесячная прибыль составляет около 4,000 сом. В целях дальнейшего расширения своего бизнеса, Алижан обратился в компанию «Бай Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 75,000 сом (KGS) на покупку скота и закупа сельхоз продукции на реализацию. В будущем, Алижан мечтает дать хорошее образование своим детям.
texts.en: Alizhan is a happy, kind and buoyant person.  He is 42 years old, married and is a father of three children.  Alizhan is a miner and works at a mine in the town of Kazarman 15 days per month.  Five years ago, in search of an additional income, he started his own business of breeding livestock and selling agricultural products at the local market.  Having started with a sum of 10,000 som (KGS), Alizhan's current monthly profit is about 4,000 som.  In order to further expand his business, Alizhan requested a loan in the sum of 75,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" for the purchase of livestock and agricultural products for sale.  In the future, Alizhan dreams of providing a good education for his children.

loans.use: to purchase livestock and agricultural crops for sale

loans.name: Emmanuel M.'s Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org based in Makeni, Northern Sierra Leone,is very pleased to present to you this group of teachers from Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to apply for a loan of 4,300,000 SLL in order to meet their immediate financial challenges. At the end of each month, they will then repay the loan using their monthly salaries. Their schools bursar is directly responsible for making the repayment on their behalf. 

Emmanuel is the leader of this group of teachers. The fifty-one-year-old was born in Bumbuna, in Northern Sierra Leone. He is married and has four children. Emmanuel has served in the teaching profession for thirty-one years now. He has applied for this loan in order to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: to pay school fees for his children.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca is 51 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has 2 children.  Rebecca has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks, & beverages . She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy canned goods, snacks ,& beverages.  Rebecca has been a member of HSPFI since 2011.  In the future, Rebecca hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, & beverages

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
"A woman with determination and love for her parents." 

Delia is single and 51 years old. She is a devoted daughter. She lives with her parents. She is the one who provides all of the needs of her parents. Delia is the one who manages the farm. That's why she is asking a loan of PHP 25,000 to purchase fertilizer and corn seed for her farm. Delia hopes that someday she can renovate her house and have a comfortable home.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and corn seed for her farm business

loans.name: Espigas De Oro Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “ESPIGAS DE ORO” iniciará su primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del centro focal Villa Adela, está compuesta por nueve integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva encabezada por la señora Martha. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: venta de comida, tejido de mantas, venta de electrodomésticos.

La señora Martha,  indica que es la primera vez que trabaja en Pro Mujer y que integro la institución por invitación de sus amigas. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de electrodomésticos y para ampliar su mercadería ahora implementará juguetes por ser temporada navideña.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para aumentar su capital (compra de juguetes) que adquirirá de La Paz y posteriormente lo venderá en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia, pues ella es soltera y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta que no exista cuota de inicio.
texts.en: The A.C. “ESPIGAS DE ORO” will begin its first season in Pro Mujer, as part of the central focal Villa Adela, and is composed of nine members headed by a board headed by Mrs. Martha. Businesses that members of the community association carry forward are varied among them are: food sales, blanket weaving, selling appliances. Martha indicates that it is the first time working in Pro Mujer and integrates the institution at the invitation of her friends. Today she has a business selling appliances and to expand her merchandise, she will now implement toys for the holiday season. The loan that she will take is to raise capital (purchase of toys) that she will acquire from La Paz and then sell it in retail space. This workflow allows her to generate resources to support her family because she is single and has three children. When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she says she likes that there is no startup fee.

loans.use: to purchase toys.

loans.name: Tulkin

texts.ru: Тулкин женат имеет троих детей. Жена домохозяйка.10 лет он занимается выращиванием ячменя и лука.Для посева следует подготовить землю, обработать минеральными удобрениями Земля приносит хорошие плоды, если ухаживать за ней. Урожай он продает оптом и часть оставляет для продажи позже.  Как поднимутся цены на товар он продает его на рынке. Тулкин хочет получить займ в размере 1500 сомони для покупки семян и ГСМ к весеннему посеву. Он будет благодарен вам, если вы его поддержите. Спасибо.
texts.en: Tulkin is married and has three children.  His wife is a homemaker.  He has been involved in growing barley and onions for ten years.  He needs to prepare the land for sowing and treat it with mineral fertilizers.  The land yields a good harvest if it is taken care of.  Tulkin sells the harvest wholesale and leaves some for a later sale.  As product prices rise, he sells it at the market.  Tulkin wants to obtain a loan in the sum of 1500 somoni to purchase seeds and fuel for the spring sowing.  He will be grateful to you, if you support him.  Thank you.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fuel

loans.name: Cerina

texts.en:
Cerina is 34 years old, widowed and lives in the Philippines. She has had a shop where she sells canned goods, snacks and beverages for the past five years.

Cerina has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. She has requested a loan of 16,000 PHP to buy additional stocks of food for her shop. She hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of food for her shop.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 35 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has 4 children. Evelyn has a food/retail shop or sari-sari store that buys & sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products & beverages. She has this business for 6 years. She requested a loan for PHP  5,000  to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks & beverages to sell.

Evelyn  has been a member of HSPFI since 2012. In the future, she hopes to improve her business for the education of her children.

loans.use: buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Fusena

texts.en: Although Fusena has received no prior formal education, she is a petty trader at Ayensudu in Elmina. She specializes in selling watermelon. She has been involved in this enterprise for some years now. Fusena is married and has three children. Her husband is a vulcanizer. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees. She will use the loan to purchase increased amounts of watermelon for supply, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales. With the new profits from her expanded business, Fusena plans to further diversify the type of products that she sells, hence adapting to changing customer preferences.

loans.use: to increase amounts of watermelon for supply, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales.

loans.name: Venus

texts.en: Venus is a 20 year old business lady who is into buying and selling of clothes and volunteer Camfed learner guide, living with her parents in Mudzi district in Zimbabwe. Her work involves running her clothing business at a rented flea market as way of generating income for the family to buy food and family food since it is the only source of income. Venus is requesting KIVA loan to make bulky purchases of clothes and shoes for reselling. She is planning to use her profit to pay school fees for her sisters  and to build her own boutique. The interest of on her “ social interest “loan will be repaid through Venus’ weekly two and half hours of volunteering as a Camfed Learner Guide.

loans.use: To make bulky purchases of clothes and shoes

loans.name: Enoe

texts.en:
My name is Enoe L. and I have been working in my clothing store for twelve years, even now I continue to have many clients because they like my manner of attending to them and my prices. In the summer months I have a large demand for shorts, short sleeve shirts, towels with scenes of our city, because we receive many tourists here. I have three school ages children who help me in their spare time.

Descripción del Negocio: Me llamo Enoe L., me dedico a la venta de ropa nueva hace doce años, hasta ahora tengo mucha clientela ya que les gusta mi manera de atenderlos y los precios. En esta época de verano tengo bastante demanda en la ropa como short, camisetas, toallas con paisajes de nuestra ciudad ya que nos visitan bastantes turistas. Tengo tres hijos en edad escolar quienes me ayudan en sus ratos libres.

loans.use: Buying trousers for men, women and children, summer clothes and underwear.

loans.name: Ulker

texts.en:
Ulkar rents a small shop where she sells foodstuffs, soaps, soap powders, shampoos. She is 47, married, has 2 children, Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of Azerbaijan Fizuli region, settled in the Finnish houses, which are built temporary on front line in Fizuli region. 
Ulkar started off working by selling as a street vendor. She saved enough money to set up a business. 
Having borrowed a loan amount of $600 she bought industrial goods. Being busy with this business she supports her family.
Now she applies for a loan amount of $800 to expand the area of her shop and to buy foodstuffs.
Ulkar has been engaged in his business for 6 years.

loans.use: To expand the area of her shop and to buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Neng

texts.en: Neng B. is 52 years old and lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and their 6 children.  Her husband works in a nearby hospital making $3/day.  Two of her daughters work in a garment factory, two are teachers, and the two youngest are in school.  With this loan, Neng B. will buy a variety of grocery products to sell in her small shop.  She is confident that she can begin to earn more than the $3/day that she currently makes, and as her business grows she will save money in order to send her children to University.  Without this loan, her family would not have enough income to send the youngest children to University.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products

loans.name: Phin

texts.en: Mrs. Phin C. is a 44-year-old widow living in Phnom Penh with her 4 children.  She works selling scallops along the roadside and her children help with her business.  This loan will be used to purchase more scallops for selling, and also to buy a motorbike so that she can transport her product to different markets.

loans.use: To purchase scallops

loans.name: Mavzuna

texts.ru:
Mavzuna M. is a happy mother of three boys. She is 36, is married and has a college education. Because her husband is currently in Russia earning money, it's up to her to take care of the family while he is gone. The children go to school. She has been selling men's clothing for 6 years now. She became a client of MicroInvest back in 2003. She borrowed $100, which allowed her to diversify her goods as well as purchase a new sales point. Her daughter-in-law helps her out with the business by working as a salesperson. Currently her assets amount to $1300 and she is planing to open yet another sales point.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva Volunteer

Малабекова Мавзуна счастливая мать, у неё три сына. Ей 36лет, образование высшее, замужем. Муж на заработках в РФ, поэтому все заботы о семье пока на её голове. Дети учатся в школе. Она занимается продажей мужской одежды 6лет. Клиентом МЗФ «Микроинвест» стала в 2003году, тогда она получила 100$, и её активы составляли 200$. После получения неоднократного займа она увеличила ассортимент товаров и приобрела новое место деятельности. В её деятельности помогает ей как продавщица её сноха. Сейчас её активы возросли до 1300$, и в будущем она планирует приобрести еще одну торговую точку.

loans.use: to open another store

loans.name: Hanadi

texts.en: Hanadi is a 42 year old woman living in Borj Barajneh, in Beirut. She has a retail  clothes shop and needs $1200 to buy clothing. She is a mother of 3 children, who is able to manage her time between her family and her professional activity.

loans.use: To buy clothes for her clothes shop

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes O. is a 58 year old woman who is married with 7 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. Agnes sells foodstuffs, a business she learnt for 3 months. She has been in the business since 1988.

Agnes is requesting a loan of $400 to enable her to buy more foodstuffs to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Nanunone's Group

texts.en:
Nanunone N. currently has a profitable canteen and wants to open a second one. She hopes to produce extra profits to help pay school fees for her 5 children and 2 orphans.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To open a second canteen

loans.name: Zenobia

texts.es:
Zenobia works breeding dairy cattle, she commercializes the milk to PIL Andina (Milk Possessing Plant). She lives with her two small children and her husband in the Community of Kallutaca, Laca sector; three and a half hours from the city of La Paz. Her husband works as bricklayer in the city of El Alto; his income helps to support their family. The loan will be use to buy improved race cattle and this way increase the milk production. This is the first loan with Impro. The evaluation made qualifies her to grant herthe loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

Zenobia se dedica a la crianza de ganado vacuno, cuya producción de leche comercializa a PIL Andina (Planta Industrializadota de Leche). Vive en la Comunidad de Kallutaca sector Laja a tres horas y media de la ciudad de La Paz, junto a sus dos pequeños hijos y su esposo el cual trabaja como albañil en la ciudad de El Alto con cuyos ingresos ayuda en el sostenimiento de la familia. El crédito lo destinara para la compra de ganado de raza mejorada y así incrementar la producción de leche. Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada le califica para otorgarle el préstamo.

loans.use: Buy improved race dairy cattle

loans.name: Ana Luisa

texts.en: Ana is 50 years old and the proud mother of four sons and one daughter, all of whom are in their twenties.  Ana makes curtains and decorative window dressings, and sells these products to customers in her community.  Ana explains that maintaining cash flow is sometimes challenging, but she expects her new curtain patterns and styles will help to repay her loan, which would be used to buy additional fabrics for her curtains and window dressings.  Ana’s husband is disabled, so she hopes that the income generated from her business will allow her and her husband to enjoy their golden years.

loans.use: To purchase new fabrics for curtains and window furnishings

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Joined TYM since 1999, Mrs. Nguyen Thi H., 38 years old, was among the first to take out a large loan in the time when many others were still caution. With the advantage of a large garden and pond, she started with raising ducks, pigs and fishes while planting fruits With over 200 ducks in her coop, the income from their eggs has been quite stable and has enable her to always repay the loan on time. Apart from these ducks, she also has many sows, 3 pole perch to raise fishes and 2 rods planting shaddock. She always like to borrow a large loan to expand business so she would also like to take out a loan of 1200 USD this time. Her family income is from 200-230 USD per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Anh H. Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Nguyễn Thị Hải, 38 tuổi, là một thành viên năng động, dám nghĩ dám làm. Tham gia Quỹ năm 1999, trong lúc nhiều thành viên khác còn ngại trong việc vay những mức vốn lớn thì chị là người đầu tiên trong cụm vay vốn đầu tư làm trang trại. Tận dụng vườn ao thuận lợi cho việc chăn nuôi, chị Hải đầu tư nuôi vịt đẻ, lợn sinh sản, ao cá và vườn cây ăn quả. Hơn 200 vịt đẻ hàng ngày cho thu nhập từ trứng rất đều dặn và ổn định là một nguồn bảo đảm chắc chắn cho việc hoàn trả hàng tuần. Ngoài số vịt đẻ hiện tại chị Hải có H. đàn lợn nái, hơn 3 sào ao thả cá và 2 sào vườn trồng bưởi diễn. Dự án của chị hứa hẹn cho một mùa thu hoạch bội thu. Chị luôn mong muốn được vay các mức vốn lớn mở rộng qui mô dự án. Mức vốn đề nghị của chị Hải lần này là 1200USD. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình là 200-230USD/tháng.

loans.use: Buy pigs, ducks and food for them

loans.name: Scola

texts.en:
Scola is a 34 year old married woman with 3 children, ages 18,15, and 8 years old. Scola owns a small food vendor store, which she started in 2002. Everyday, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $65 from her sales.

In the past, Scola has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Dem

texts.en: Dem S. is 28 years old and a housewife in Kampong Cham province. Her husband earns the household money by managing a small taxi business. He organizes the transport of people and goods between Phnom Penh and Kampong Cham through a number of drivers with their own vehicles. He earn $15 (U.S.)  per day through this job and has no other costs to detract from his income. On this salary he supports his wife and only child. He wants to replace one of his older taxis with a newer one. The family’s loan will go towards hiring out this car, which he hopes will increase their income.

loans.use: To buy a new car for a taxi

loans.name: Malaneh But Group

texts.en:
Kadiatu T. is very grateful to Kiva for the $200 loan that enabled her to expand her business. She said the loan was a real seed that has multiplied. With the profit, she was able to meet her children's college expenses and started building her business capital.

Kadiatu, together with her group members Memunata, Amie, Sallamatu and Kadiatu K., sells palm oil, rice, peanuts and kola nuts. Memunata also sells used clothes.

The group would like to further expand their businesses and so they are requesting a loan of Le.4000000 ($US1,375).

loans.use: Increase stocks of rice, palm oil, peanuts and bails of used clothes.

loans.name: Koffi

texts.fr:
A young teacher by profession, Koffi A. gardens on the side. Married and the father of one child, Mr. A. adds to his income from the sale of his garden produce, to be able to better provide for the needs of his small family. His clientele has grown significantly of late, and anxious to meet this demand Mr. A. is seeking financial support to purchase pesticides and a large quantity of seed. If granted, this loan would permit him to better cover family expenses and to increase their standard of living.

Translated from French by Joyce, Kiva Volunteer.

Jeune Enseignant de profession, Monsieur A. Koffi à pour activité secondaire le jardinage. Marié et père d’un enfant, Monsieur A. joint les revenus de la vente des produits de son jardin pour pouvoir subvenir un temps soit peu aux besoins de sa petite famille. De nos jours la demande des clients devient de plus en plus considérable, dans le souci de couvrir cette demande Monsieur A. Koffi sollicite un appui financier pour s’acheter les produits phytosanitaires et les semences en grand nombre. Ce crédit octroyé lui permettra de mieux couvrir les dépenses de sa famille et augmenter son niveau de vie.

loans.use: Purchase of seed and pesticide

loans.name: Kokoè Victori

texts.fr:
Née en 1978 à Aklakou au TOGO, Madame A. Kokoè Victorine est une revendeuse de riz depuis quatre ans. Elle est mariée et à trois personnes à charge. N’ayant pas d’important fonds de commerce, elle ne parvient pas à satisfaire à la forte demande de sa clientèle nombreuse.

Par conséquent, elle n’arrive pas à dégager assez de bénéfice devant lui permettre de répondre aux multiples besoins du ménage. 

Dans le souci d’augmenter son pouvoir d’achat en vue de maximiser de bénéfice pour améliorer les conditions et niveau de vie de sa famille, elle sollicite un crédit. Ceci lui servira de fonds de roulement susceptible de sécuriser son revenu.
texts.en:
Born in 1978 in Aklakou, Togo, Mrs. Kokoè Victorine A. has been selling cooked rice for four years. She is married and responsible for three persons. Lacking significant business capital, she does not manage to supply the demand of her numerous customers.

For this reason, she is not able to make enough income to allow her to cover the many needs of her household.

Intent on increasing her buying power so as to maximize her profit to improve living conditions for her family, she is requesting a loan. This will serve as business capital which should allow her to earn a living wage.


Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase, preparation, and sale of rice

loans.name: Anela

texts.en:
Anela O. is 24 years old and she lives in little town, Kalesija, near Tuzla. She is married and she has a four-year-old daughter. Her husband is employed and he earns 1400 KM monthly. Anela wants to create better living conditions for her family, so she has decided to take a loan with WWI.

This is her first loan in the amount of 600 KM. She wants to buy poultry for fattening and selling. Anela hopes that she will have success in her business and that she will be able to work and sell more.

loans.use: To buy poultry to raise

loans.name: Elina

texts.es:
La Señora Elina es socia del Grupo de Crédito Mientras Tanto “Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria”, vive en la región  y  provincia de  San Martín, distrito de  Tarapoto. Se dedica a la venta de abarrotes y se inicia en vista que en su barrio no hay este tipo de negocio y también porque quería generar sus ingresos y contribuir en la economía de su hogar. El negocio está ubicado en su propia casa en el Jr. Alfonso Ugarte Nº 2137, lugar donde espera a sus clientes para atenderlos con mucha amabilidad.

Con este préstamo de S/.1,000, el cual será cancelado en 6  meses, comprará  productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar en saco, leche, aceite, conservas en cajas de diferentes tamaños, así como juguetes, papel higiénico en paquetes, detergentes, jabones de diferentes marcas y tamaños, entre otros,  y de esa manera surtir bien el negocio y que sus clientes encuentren lo que buscan. 

Elina tiene 26 años de edad, vive con su esposo y su hija, Es una mujer trabajadora, carismática y con muchas ganas de seguir trabajando para hacer crecer su negocio, ya que le gusta lo que hace. Su meta  es continuar con su negocio, seguir creciendo y tenerlo bien surtido para la satisfacción tanto de ella y como la de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Señora Elina is a member of the interim group "Las Vencedoras de Villa Universitaria". She lives in the region and province of San Martín in the district of Tarapoto. She sells groceries, and she started this business because there wasn't a business of this kind in her neighborhood and also because she wanted to earn an income and contribute to her family's finances. Her business is located in her home at Jr. Alfonso Ugarte Nº 2137, a place where she awaits to attend to her customers with much kindness.

With this loan of 1,000 nuevos soles, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will buy basic goods like rice, sugar in sacks, milk, oil, canned goods of different sizes, toys, toilet paper in packages, detergent, soap of different brands and sizes, etc. In this way she will supply her business well and her customers will find what they are looking for.

Elina is 26-years-old and lives with her husband and daughter. She is a hard-working, charismatic woman who wants to keep working to grow her business, sinces she likes what she does. Her goal is to continue with her business, to keep growing, and to have it well-supplied for her own and her customers' satisfaction.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will purchase basic goods (rice, sugar, milk, oil, etc.)

loans.name: Ndeshi

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Ndeshi M. from Mwanza. She is married with two children, ages three and nine. Ndeshi has been running a clothing business since 2008. She works at her business for 12 hours a day, six days a week. Ndeshi currently earns about 150 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase vitenge (African traditional clothing), shirts, children's clothes and trousers. Ndeshi thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase clothing for resale

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana is a member of the Amor y Esperanza (“Love and Hope”) Village Bank. Juana is 49 years old and lives with her common-law husband and their three children. 

Juana has a stand at the Grau Market, where she sells meat. She travels to regional markets twice per week to buy cows, which she then takes to the city slaughterhouse. Juana also sells homemade ice cream, which she makes with milk, sesame seeds and sugar. 

Juana needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy meat, sugar and sesame seeds. Juana’s dreams are for her children to graduate with professional degrees, to expand her business, and to finish building her house.

loans.use: Buy meat, sesame seeds and sugar

loans.name: Kalambène Group

texts.fr:
http://sem-fund.org/oussouye.php 
Pour une deuxième fois, nous venons solliciter auprès de Kiva un prêt pour mener des activités génératrices de revenus. Nous avions dans le passé reçu un prêt qui nous a beaucoup aidé à voir comment gerer un microcrédit et maintenant nous voulons faires des investissements pour faire un travail durable comme par exemple faire de la teinture de tissus et la vente du produit fini dans les hotels et boutiques de notre écovillage. Avec les gains de notre premiers prêt, nous avons satisfait aux besoins de nos familles respectives:(ecole, santé) et aussi nous sommes parvenues à nous prendre en charge nous même. Cette fois-ci le prêt vas nous permettre de travailler sur une plus large échelle et va impliquer plusieurs personnes( environs douze); Nous savons que nous pouvons compter sur Kiva car c'est le seul partenaire qui nous prête de l'argent sans condition et vite fait.
texts.en:
This will be the second loan that we have solicited from Kiva. The loan will be used to support activities that will generate revenue. We have in the past, received a loan that assisted us greatly and showed us how to manage a micro-loan. Now,we would like to make investments, along with hard work to produce for example; the dying of cloth and the sale of the finished product to the hotels and boutiques within the Ecovillage Fund group. With the profits made from our first loan we were able to satisfy the needs of our individual families ( school, health) as well as meet our responsibilities. This second loan will allow us to work on a larger scale and will involve several more persons (about twelve). We know that we can count on Kiva as they are a partner who can quickly lend funds without conditions.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cloth, dyes and other items used in the dying process

loans.name: Sinjiya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Sinjiya (composé de 6 femmes  mariées) ont une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans avec en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles résident dans le quartier  Babemba de la ville de sikasso.
Elles  exercent des activités commerciales différentes mais la plus dominante est la vente de condiments à laquelle s’ajoutent les ventes d’habits  pour enfant, du savon et de pagnes wax et real.
Elles collaborent avec  l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso  pour satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).Les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 2 douzaines de vêtements   pour enfants, 8 pièces de pagnes wax et real, 10 cartons de savons importés et 3  colis de condiments. Elles s’approvisionnent sur place à Sikasso et environnants.
Les produits sont vendus en détail et au comptant dans les marchés de la ville de Sikasso (Médine et le grand marché de la ville) et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 17.500 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.  
Elles souhaitent continuer leur collaboration avec SORO YIRIWASO, afin de pouvoir devenir chacune d’elle une grossiste de bonne renommée.
texts.en:
The members of the group Sinjiya are composed of six married women who average 35 years of age and three children. They reside in the Babemba district of the city of Sikasso and work in various kinds of commerce, but the most predominant is the sale of condiments, plus children’s clothing, soap, and “pagnes” (colorful West African cloth).

To satisfy the needs of their customers, they collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their third solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding ones have been correctly repaid. They plan to use this loan to buy 2 dozen pieces of clothing for children, 8 lengths of WAX and REAL brand pagnes, 10 boxes of imported soap, and 3 packages of condiments. Supplies are gotten locally in Sikasso and in surrounding areas. The goods are sold retail and for cash in the marketplaces of Sikasso (Médine and the grand marketplace of the city) and in the districts, to customers composed of women and men.

The group members each hope to realize a monthly profit of 17,500 francs CFA that will be used to pay the loan interest, provide for the family, and to invest the rest in their businesses. They would like to continue their collaboration with SORO YIRIWASO in order to become reputable wholesalers, each one of them.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments, children's clothing, soap, and cloth

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary B. is married and has 3 children. She has received schooling through junior high. Mary sells cosmetics and bags of salt, which she has done since 2000. Her husband is a nurse. Mary uses her income to pay for house keeping expenses. Mary will use the loan to purchase more cosmetics and bags of salt to meet the increase in demand by her costumers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to develop a plot of land which she bought with her husband to pay for their house.

loans.use: Mary will use the loan to purchase more cosmetics and bags of salt to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Lusgarda

texts.es:
La señora Lusgarda T. P., pertenece al Banco Comunal “Santa Bárbara”, vive en el Jr. Cuzco Nº 396, Distrito de Tarapoto, departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 34 años y es madre 02 hijos, que todavía depende de ella.

Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, motivada por una amiga empezó vendiendo frutas en el Mercado de Tarapoto.
Tiene 01 año trabajando con el Banco.

En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de comidas preparadas, anticuchos asados y juanes, ubicada en el Jr. Cuzco Nº 396, donde vende a sus clientes, vecinos y moradores de la comunidad y con el préstamo de S/1,300.00 que cancelará a plazo de 04 meses, desea invertirlo, implementando su negocio, comprar más mesas, sillas, vasos y ollas y así dar una mejor atención y comodidad a sus clientes.

En lo personal, desea ampliar más su negocio, y hoy se siente más responsable con el pago de sus cuotas y toma sus propias decisiones.

Lusgarda, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lusgarda T. P. is a member of the community bank Santa Barbara. She lives at Jr. Cuzco Number 396 in the Tarapoto district in the department of San Martín. She is 34 years old, married, and the mother of two dependent children. With the first loan of 300.00 soles, and motivated by a friend, she began selling fruits in the Tarapoto market. She has been working with the bank for 1 year. Now she sells prepared meals, such as grilled kabobs and “juanes” (a traditional dish). Her business is located at Jr. Cuzco number 396. She sells to customers, neighbors and residents of the community. With this loan for 1,300.00 soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will build up her business. She will buy tables, chairs, glasses and pots. This will make her customers more comfortable, and allow her to provide better service. Personally, she wishes to expand her business. She now feels more responsible about making her payments and making her own decisions. Lusgarda is grateful to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow as a business person and as a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more tables, chairs, glasses and pots

loans.name: Shukur

texts.ru: Шукур пунктуально погасив свой кредит, подал заявку на очередной кредит.Этот займ он хочет потратить на закуп коров и корма для них.Шукур очень опытный в бизнесе животноводства.Его коровы в день дают по 7 литров молока.Из которого его жена производит домашний кефир.Шукур рад сотрудничать с Микроинвест.
texts.en:
Shukur after punctually paying off his loan, has applied for another one. He would like to use this loan to purchase cows and feed. Shukur is very experienced in the livestock business. His cows produce 7 liters of milk per day per cow. Shukur’s wife makes homemade yogurt from the milk. Shukur is happy to work together with MicroInvest.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cows and feed

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn has been operating a sari-sari store (a community-based store) in her village for more than the 20 years since she got married. She is married to Romeo and they were gifted with two children: Ryan, 24 years old, a graduate of a two-year vocational course in automotives and Rhey Jay, 19 years old, a college student. According to Marilyn, she is proud that her children grew up with discipline and respect.

She is now requesting a loan amounting to 11,000 Philippine Pesos to be used buying more groceries for her store. She is really striving to the best of her ability to succeed in this kind of business. She dreams for her youngest child to finish his studies and find a good job some day. “Trust in the Lord with all your heart, with all your soul, with your entire mind, and with all your strength so you will be helped by Him”, said Marilyn.

loans.use: To buy groceries for resale

loans.name: Santiago

texts.es: Santiago es un joven de 29 años, muy alegre y conciente de que tiene que trabajar duro para sobresalir en la vida, vive en la casa de sus padres a quienes desea dar una buena vejez. Santiago pasa sus días manejando su taxi, no importa si es de día o de noche, sigue recorriendo las calles en busca de clientes que deseen llegar sanos y seguros a su destino, su ánimo alegre y sus dotes de conversador hacen que los clientes lo busquen para que los movilice, además que conoce muy bien las calles de la ciudad de Puno y siempre brinda un servicio rápido. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es pasear por las calles, ya que se distrae mucho, lleva 10 años realizando este trabajo y lo que menos le gusta es tener que lidiar con algunos pasajeros que no quieren pagar, aun así sabe que ese es su trabajo y tiene que realizarlo. Para el futuro espera comprar otro taxi y hacerlo trabajar para mejorar sus ingresos. Este es el primer préstamo de Santiago con MFP y está dispuesto a pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo, en su banco comunal es un socio muy responsable y solidario. Con los 1000 soles que solicita hará arreglar su taxi, que con el paso del tiempo ha ido sufriendo daños.
texts.en:
Santiago is a young man who is 29 years old. He is very happy and aware that he has to work hard to survive in life. He lives in his parents’ house, and he wants to give them a good old age. Santiago drives a taxi. It doesn’t matter if it’s day or night; he continues traveling the streets in search of clients that want to arrive safely and soundly at their destination. He has a happy demeanor, and his conversational skills make his clients look for him to take them around. In addition, he knows the streets in the city of Puno well and always offers a fast service. What he likes most about his work is driving through the streets, since it passes the time. He has spent 10 years in this job, and what he likes least is to have to fight with some passengers that don’t want to pay, even though they know this is his job and he has to do it. For the future, he hopes to buy another taxi and use it for work in order to improve his earnings. This is Santiago’s first loan with MFP, and he is ready to pay all of her payments on time. He is a very responsible and supportive member of his community bank. With the 1000 soles that she requests, he will repair his taxi, which, over time, has been damaged.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair his taxi

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita L. is from the town of Lopez Jaena. She is 58 years old. Lolita is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Lolita owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Lolita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Lolita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị

texts.en:
Nguyễn Thị H. is a 40 year-old female living in the town of Đô Lương.  She is married and has 2 adult -aged children.  To make a living,  Nguyễn Thị owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling rice products in the local community.  She has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2500000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2007,  Nguyễn Thị  joined the TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000000 VND from the TYM Fund.  This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Nguyễn Thị  is now requesting a new loan of 9000000 VND which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.  The loan will be the 4th loan she has taken out. Nguyễn Thị plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Soloi

texts.en: Soloi I., 32, is married with 4 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the taxi business.  She provides service to people 6 days per week.  She has no previous loans with SPBD.  Soloi expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).   SPBD loans are Soloi’s only access to capital because she is not able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase taxi wheels,windows,battery.

loans.name: Aunty

texts.en: Aunty is a businesswoman. She trades in Dumas clothes, linen and lace materials. She mostly sells through hawking - a personal selling method that she says makes her goods move very fast. She is 46 years old and a married mother with three children. All her children are in school. She supports her family through the proceeds she makes from the business. She has eight years of marketing experience but progress has been persistently slow due to insufficient funds. She hopes this loan will enable her to revive the business and make it more profitable. She wants to purchase Dumas clothes, linen and lace materials in bulk to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase Dumas clothes in bulk

loans.name: Epenesa

texts.en:
Epenesa M. is a 63-year-old woman living in the town of Safaatoa Uta.  She is married with six adult children.  Epenesa owns and operates a general store.  While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products to the local community.  Epenesa has had this business for over six years and earns approximately 2000 WST a month.

Epenesa joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Epenesa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3250 WST from SPBD.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  Epenesa is now requesting a new loan of 3950 WST for the same purpose.  The loan will her seventh loan from SPBD.  Epenesa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About SPBD:
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline D. is from the village of Bulao, Iponan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 46 years old. Evangeline is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Evangeline owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies through consignment basis in the local community. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Evangeline joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evangeline is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Evangeline from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

location.town: Bulao, Iponan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Hayde Veronica

texts.es:
La señora Hayde es socia del Banco Comunal “Señor de la Caña”  que esta ubicado de el distrito de Plateria, Provincia de Puno, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 29 años de edad, estado civil soltera y es madre de 03 hijos y tiene estudios de secundaria completa, vive en el distrito de Plateria.

La señora trabaja con el movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 02 años, su préstamo inicial fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles  este dinero lo invirtió en la compra de lana para elaboración de artesanías. 

En este momento ella solicito un préstamo de S/. 600.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de lana de diferentes colores para la elaboración de artesanías, el mismo que los vende en las ferias.

Su mayor sueño tener una pequeña empresa de artesanía.

A ella le gustan los ahorros y las facilidades en los préstamos
texts.en:
Ms. Hayde A. is a member of the “Señor de la Caña” Communal Bank, located in the Plateria district of the Puno province, department of Puno. She is a 29-year-old single mother with 3 children who lives in Plateria and has a high school diploma. Ms. A. has been working with the Manuela Ramos movement for 2 years. She used her initial loan in the amount of 300.00 PEN to purchase wool to make handicrafts. At this time, she is requesting a 600.00 PEN loan to purchase wool in assorted colors to make handicrafts, which she will then sell at different markets. Her biggest dream is to have her own small handicraft company. She likes the savings offered by her bank, and the ease of obtaining loans.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wool

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita R. is from the village of Gumbil, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 21 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2004, Teresita joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell in future. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be her seventh from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Shakarmo

texts.en:
S. Shakarmo is a very hardworking and independent woman. She has three kids, two of whom she still supports and who are in elementary and high school, respectively. In search of a way to support her household, she started selling groceries 17 years ago. A true entrepreneur, she studies the market to determine client needs and preferences. Industrious and enterprising, Shakarmo is focused on expanding her business. At the same time with the help of her children Shakarmo raises cattle. In order to grow her business, Shakarmo is requesting a loan of 6400 Somoni ($1475 USD), which she will use to purchase foodstuff to be able to offer a wider selection to her customers and increase her income. With the part of the loan she will also buy young cattle. With the increased sales and profits, Shakarmo hopes to expand her grocery and improve the living standards of her family. The well being of Shakarmo’s family and her business are in your hands. Shakarmo and her children are sincerely grateful for your support.  
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Foodstuff for selling for increasing of the range of goods

loans.name: Jigjidsuren

texts.en:
L. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and two children in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in one of the ger districts on the outskirts of the city. Her two children, ages 15 and 13, both attend a local secondary school.

L. operates a noodle-producing shop with the help of her husband. They began the business in 2007 with no employees other than themselves. Since then, they have been able to hire 6 employees, and their working capital exceeds 2,500,000 tugrugs (~1750 USD). L. would like to keep growing her business and be able to hire even more people in the future so that this business not only helps her family, but the families of her employees. She is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) in order to purchase a large amount of flour used in the production of noodles.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of flour to make noodles

loans.name: Tol

texts.en:
Mr. Tol S., 50, and his wife, Mrs. Saros Sen, 39, were married in 1983 and have six children: four sons and two daughters. The family lives along National Road Number Six, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Tol's wife is in the picture. 

Tol and his wife have been fishing for over 30 years. They fish from Mekong River and lakes near the village and sell in the village market. Some of his fishing materials (fishing nets) are old, and they break down and don’t work well. So, he is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase new fishing nets to continue his fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase new fishing nets

loans.name: Nelita

texts.en:
Nelita P. is from the village of Liong, Guinsiliban Camiguin Province. She is 38 years old. Nelita is married and has 2 school-age children. To make a living, Nelita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Nelita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Nelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Maria Rosario

texts.es:
Nuestra socia MARIA tiene 46 años, es madre soltera y tiene dos hijos. La socia se dedica por la mañanas a la enseñanza. la socia es profesora D. colegio “Valentin Paniagua”. Ella es natural de la ciudad de Cusco. La socia pertenece al banco comunal “RICCHARY CUSCO” de la Asociación Arariwa. 

La socia alterna sus actividades D. hogar con el negocio de venta ropa y zapatos. Ya son varios años con el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para hacer mas pedidos de zapatos a las tiendas mayoristas y venderlas en estas fiestas navideñas.         
   
La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Our partner Maria is 46 years old and is a single mother with two children. This partner's profession is teaching in the morning. The member is a teacher at the "Valentín Paniagua" school. She is a native of the city of Cusco. This member belongs to the "RICCHARY CUSCO" communal bank of the Association Arariwa. The member alternates her time between household activities and that of her business of selling clothes and shoes. It has been several years with this business and has done very well thanks to all the effort put into her work. Our partner is hard-working and enterprising, as she wants to support her family moving forward in life. The member requires a loan to make more orders of shoes at wholesale and then sell them in stores this holiday season. The partner is grateful for the opportunity afforded by this loan and likewise willing to abide by repayment schedule for her loan.

Translated from Spanish by Zal Bilimoria, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more shoes for sale during the holiday season

loans.name: San Pablo Group

texts.es:
El contacto para el  inicio del presente comité fue la señora Gladis M. quien se informo del programa, organizó e  invito a sus amigas y vecinas para formar parte del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras.

La sra. Gladis M. se dedica a la venta de comestible, invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumo para la elaboración de los comestibles, logrando de ese modo ofrecer mayor cantidad de minutas a su clientela.

La sra. Hilaria R. posee una almacén, invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercadería en  general (azucar, yerba, lacteos, harina, bebidas, etc.) de manera que pueda ofrecer buena variedad de mercaderias  sus clientes.

La sra. Cristina O. se dedica a la venta de Frutas y verduras, invirtió el dinero en la compra de Frutas y verduras en general logrando ofrecer buena variedad de frutas y verduras a sus clientes. 

La sra. Bernardsa Alfonzo posee una despensa, invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercadería en  general (azucar, yerba, lacteos, harina, bebidas, etc.) de manera que pueda ofrecer buena variedad de mercaderías  sus clientes.

La sra. Leonisia S. a la venta de comestible, invirtió su dinero en la compra de ingredientes para la elaboración de los comestibles, logrando de ese modo ofrecer buena variedad de minutas  a  sus clientes.

La sra. Alicia R. se decia a  la venta de prendas en  general, invirtió el dinero en la compra de prendas en general, logrando de esa manera ofrecer mayor variedad de prendas a a su clientela.

La sra. Basilicia Trocho dedica es modista, invirtió el dinero en la compra de elementos para su trabajo (tela, hilo, goma) logrando de ese modo ofrecer mayor variedad de prendas a sus clientes. 

La sra. Eusebia M. posee una almacén, invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías en general, logrando así surtir su mercadería y ofrecer buena variedad a sus clientes.

La sra. Silvia D. se dedica a la venta de Frutas, invirtió el dinero en la compra de frutas en general, logrando obtener mayor variedad de frutas que ofrecer a sus clientes.

La sra. Estelvina Galeano se dedica a la venta de frutas en general, invirtió el dinero en la compra de frutas en general, logrando de ese modo ofrecer mayor variedad de grutas a sus clientes.

La sra. Magdalena A. se dedica a la venta de  verduras y frutas, invirtió el dinero en la compra de verduras y frutas en general (al por mayor), logrando de ese modo surtir su mercaderías y abastecer la demanda de sus clientes.

La sra. Lilian C. se dedica a venta de ropas en general, invirtió el dinero en la compra de ropas en general logrando así ofrecer buena variedad de prendas de vestir a sus clientes.

La sra. Isabel R. se dedica a la costura, invirtió el dinero en la compra de elementos para su trabajo hilos, telas,accesorios, obteniendo de ese modo variedad de prendas que ofrecer a sus clientes.

La sra. Carla O. se dedica a la venta de comestible y bebidas, invirtió el dinero en la compra de ingredientes para la elaboración de los comestibles y bebidas, logrando de ese modo ofrece buena variedad de minutas y bebidas frías a sus clientes.

La sra. Brigida A. se dedica a la costura, invirtió el dinero en la compra de elementos para su trabajo tijera, tela, hilos, accesorios logrando de ese modo ofrece buena variedad de prendas a su clientela
  
La sra. Narcisa C. se dedica a la venta de comestible, invirtió el dinero en la compra de ingredientes para la elaboración de los comestibles, logrando así  ofrecer buena variedad de minutas a sus clientes.
texts.en:
The contact for the initiation of this group was Mrs.Gladys M. who, upon learning of the program, organized and invited friends and neighbors to join the "Committee of Enterprising Women" group. Gladis M. sells food, and invested the money in the purchase of supplies for the production of food, managing in this way to offer a greater variety of menu items to her customers. Hilaria R. has a store. She invested the money in the purchase of general merchandise (sugar, yerba, dairy products, flour, drinks, etc.) so that she can offer a good variety of merchandise to her customers. Cristina O. sells fruits and vegetables; she invested the money in the purchase of fruit and vegetables in general, obtaining a good variety of fruit and vegetables for her customers. Bernardsa Alfonzo has a store, She invested the money in the purchase of general merchandise (sugar, yerba, dairy products, flour, drinks, etc.) so that she can offer a good variety of merchandise to her customers. Leonisia S. sells food. She invested the money in the purchase of ingredients to use in the production of food, managing in this way to offer a greater quantity of menu items to her customers. Alicia R. sells clothing. She invested the money in the purchase of clothing in general, managing in this way to offer a greater variety of clothing to her customers. Basilicia Trocho is a seamstress. She invested the money in the purchase of items for her work (fabric, thread, glue), managing in this way to offer an increased variety of garments for her customers. Eusebia M. has a store; she invested the money in the purchase of general merchandise, managing thereby to supply her store with merchandise and offer a good variety of products to her customers. Silvia D. and Estelvina Galeano sell fruit; they invested the money in the purchase of fruit in general, obtaining a good variety of fruit that they can offer their customers. Magdalena A. sells fruits and vegetables; she invested the money in the purchase of fruit and vegetables in general (at wholesale), obtaining in this way a supply of merchandise that will meet the demand of her customers. Lilian C. sells clothing. She invested the money in the purchase of clothing in general, managing in this way to offer a greater variety of clothing to her customers. Isabel R. is a seamstress. She invested the money in the purchase of items for her work (fabric, thread, accessories), in this way managing to offer an increased variety of garments for her customers. Carla O. sells food and drinks. She invested the money in the purchase of ingredients to use in the production of food and drinks, managing in this way to offer a greater quantity of menu items and cold drinks to her customers. Brigida A. is a seamstress. She invested the money in the purchase of items for her work (scissors, fabric, thread, accessories), in this way managing to offer an increased variety of garments for her customers. Narcisa C. sells food. She invested the money in the purchase of ingredients to use in the production of food, managing in this way to offer a greater quantity of menu items to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy clothing, drinks, meat, , bebidas, carnes, sausages, bread, yerba, cooking oil, sweets, vegetables, fruit, candy, dairy products, notions, scissors, cleaning products, etc.

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
Emelyn C. is a 42-year-old married woman who lives in the village of Brgy Gil Montilla, Sipalay City Negros Occidental. Her business is buying and selling rice, operating a farm shop, a piggery and a restaurant/carenderia.

Emelyn C.’s husband helps her run the business and they have two children who are 17 and 22 years old, respectively. The children are currently going to school and helping their parents run the business as part of their daily chores.

Emelyn C. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase the family income by maintaining and growing her various businesses.  Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000 from her business activities.

Emelyn C. is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 was used to fund the operations of her various businesses, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500, which she intends to use for additional working capital and to purchase farm equipment. Emelyn C. is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital and to purchase farm equipment

loans.name: Maïmounatou

texts.fr: Née en 1986, D. Maïmounatou est mariée à SADIKOU Kolawolé un transitaire, et est mère de trois enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. La famille vit depuis 5 ans environs à Sèkandji, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la maison. N’ayant jamais été à l’école, Maïmounatou mène comme activité, la vente de bouillie de maïs et de « tapioca » (fait à base de manioc), accompagnée de lait et du sucre, au parc DAS sur la route allant à Porto-Novo. Maïmounatou se ravitaille à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Parakou dans le Nord du Bénin. Il y a environs trois ans que Maïmounatou mène cette activité, activité qui lui génère des revenus qu’elle utilise pour subvenir à ses différents besoins. Maïmounatou a déjà obtenu deux prêts qu’elle a bien remboursés à ALIDé. Actuellement, face à la demande de plus en plus importante de ses clients, Maïmounatou éprouve des difficultés pour satisfaire tous ses clients. Maïmounatou souhaiterait agrandir son activité et mieux faire face aux besoins des clients. C’est ce qui amène Maïmounatou à solliciter un troisième prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1986, D. Maïmounatou is married to SADIKOU Kolawolé, a forwarding agent, and is the mother of three children. All three children are enrolled in school. The family has been living for about 5 years in Sèkandji, in the township of Sèmè-Podji in Bénin. The couple share in supporting the household.

Never having been to school, Maïmounatou sells maize porridge and "tapioca" porridge (made of manioc) with milk and sugar, at the DAS truck stop on the road to Porto-Novo. Maïmounatou buys her ingredients in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin, and also in Parakou in the north of Bénin. She has been in this business for about 3 years, and the income from it is what she uses to support herself.

Maïmounatou has already received two loans that she correctly reimbursed to ALIDé. Presently, due to increasing demand from her clientele, Maïmounatou is having difficulty satisfying all their needs. She would like to expand her business so as to satisfy her customers. This is what leads her to ask for a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of maize, tapioca, sugar and milk

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 51 years old and married with nine children ranging in age from 31 down to 11 years old. Four of the children are currently attending school. She operates a mixed farm in western Kenya, just outside the city of Kitale. She's been farming for eight years and sells eggs and milk products at the local retail outlets near her home. She also earns income from her involvement in other horticulture activities and in making and selling charcoal. She says that the main challenges to her business are the high prices for chicken feed and her overall high expenses in maintaining the farm.

Jane requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 30,000 to purchase material that will enable her to build a bigger poultry house.  She also will be purchasing other farm inputs for the upcoming season. She said that this loan will help increase the family's income and diversify her production into more poultry and dairy farming. In the future, she would like to own at least five dairy animals at her farm.

Jane recently completed her first loan through Juhudi Kilimo before applying for this loan and she appreciates the changes in her life.  She hopes to maintain a relationship with the institution and build up her credit levels so she can purchase a dairy animal in the near future.

loans.use: Build a bigger poultry house

loans.name: Zenny Aiza

texts.en:
Zenny Aiza A. is from the village of Catuan, Gingoog City. She is 23 years old and single. To make a living, Zenny Aiza owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Zenny Aiza has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Zenny Aiza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenny Aiza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Zenny Aiza is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Zenny Aiza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe F. is from the village of Militar, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 42 years old, is married, and has five adult children. Fe owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling food for snacks, candies, shampoo, soap, sugar, etc., in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Fe joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Fe is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Plumkor Community Group

texts.en:
Plumkor Community Development Project is a group of five borrowers led by Momo K., a 43-year-old married man. Momo has three children aged 8 to 13 years old with educational levels of 4th to 7th grade.

Momo is a high school graduate but could not continue to university due to lack of financial support. He then decided to get into business. He lives in Plumkor Community which is a very poor and crowded community where people strive for their living. It is near Monrovia, the capital of Liberia.

Momo's business is timber. He buys timber whole sourced from rural Liberia and sells to the residents of Monrovia. He started this business through the efforts of friends. Because it was during the Liberian civil crisis that Momo started his business, he used to face difficulties from rebels that always seized his goods. But, because he kept his head up, he was always trying to succeed.

Momo maintains his customers by selling good timber. He has been running this business for nine years and is hoping to improve his business to a better standard. He needs this loan to buy more timber to improve business.

Momo plans to use his 26,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 80,400 Liberian dollar loan to buy more wood planks.  His dream is to open a storefront one day.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Momo is the one holding the sign.

  
About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To purchase additional wood planks.

loans.name: Reynaldo Bismarck

texts.es: Don Reynaldo es un hombre trabajador, padre de familia de dos hijas, su negocio lo formo hace varios años,  producto de su trabajo como electricista  domiciliar. Logro poner una ferretería que junto a su esposa administran los cuales hacen turnos. Ya que ella  hace los oficios de la casa y de esta manera logran ahorrar dinero. Sus hijas aun cursan el año escolar. Don Reynaldo comenzó con pocos productos y con mucha deseo de escalar, para ofrecer todos los productos de construcción ya que la demanda es mucho. La meta que tiene es lograr hacer más grande el local de la ferretería como invertir en pintura, hierro, lámparas, zinc entre otros productos para aumentar las ventas. Que espera lograr con el financiamiento ya que le ofrece plazo lo que es para el de muchos beneficios.
texts.en:
Don Reynaldo is a hard working man. He is a family man, a father to two daughters. He started his business several years ago, as a result of his job as a house electricist. He was able to open a hardware store that he and his wife manage in shifts. She manages the home and in this way they are able to save money. His daughters are still in the middle of their schoolyear. Don Reynaldo began with few products and with a strong desire to grow to offer all construction products, since demand is high. His goal is to make the hardware store locale bigger in order to invest in paint, hardware, lamps, and zinc, among other products, to increase sales. He hopes to do this with the financing since it offers him conditions that are very beneficial to him.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: He will buy paint, hardware, lamps, and zinc since he has few of these products and they sell well.

loans.name: Jessica's Group

texts.en:
Jessica J. is from the village of San Pablo, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is the leader of an 11-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
